text: <think>We are given: Let f(r)= sum_{j=2}^{2008} 1/j^r = 1/2^r + 1/3^r+ ... +1/2008^r. Find S = sum_{k=2}^{∞} f(k). That is, sum_{k=2}^{∞} f(k) = sum_{k=2}^{∞} sum_{j=2}^{2008} 1/j^k = sum_{j=2}^{2008} sum_{k=2}^{∞} 1/j^k. Interchange order if absolutely convergent.

text: Now simplify sum_{j=2}^{2008} 1/(j*(j-1)). But note that 1/(j*(j-1)) can be telescoped: 1/(j*(j-1)) = 1/(j-1) - 1/j. Let's check: 1/(j-1) - 1/j = (j - (j-1))/(j(j-1)) = 1/(j(j-1)). So indeed.

This is a geometric series with first term 1/j² and common ratio 1/j. Since |1/j| < 1, the sum is:
  A = (1/j²) / (1 - 1/j).

text:
Step 4. Recognize the telescoping form:
  Notice that
    1/(j(j - 1)) = 1/(j - 1) - 1/j.
This can be verified by writing:
  1/(j - 1) - 1/j = (j - (j - 1))/(j(j - 1)) = 1/(j(j - 1)).
reason_gemini: Recognizing and verifying the telescoping form of the expression. This involves algebraic manipulation to rewrite the fraction.
